1554.meaning_1: having a different perception; perceiving otherwise; with different opinions
1554.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
This compound describes beings who perceive or consider things differently from others, as in the referenced Sutta passage. The kammadhāraya construction indicates "one whose perception is otherwise".
1554.example_1: Because there are beings who have different opinions on this topic.

38837.meaning_1: neither material nor formless; neither with form nor formless
38837.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In DN 29 this adjective describes an attā (self/being) that is neither material (with form) nor formless, thus negating both material and immaterial conceptions of self.

4226.meaning_2: untroubled; without cause for distress; not marked by danger
4226.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the given context (dn30:1.5.5), 'animitta' describes land that is 'untroubled' or 'free from sign of danger.' The sense focuses less on abstract or meditative 'signlessness', and more on the absence of threats, disruptions, or markers of danger.
4226.sutta_1: so imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakaṃ iddhaṃ phītaṃ khemaṃ sivaṃ nirabbudaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
4226.example_1: After conquering this land girt by sea—free of harassment by bandits, successful and prosperous, safe, blessed, and untroubled—he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

11282.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context of DN30, samattam ācari (samantam ācari) means “performed (it) completely; thoroughly fulfilled”. The verb expresses the successful completion or carrying out of wholesome actions and conduct.
11282.example_1:
sacce ca dhamme ca dame ca saṃyame,
soceyyasīlālayuposathesu ca,
dāne ahiṃsāya asāhase rato,
daḷhaṃ samādāya samattamācari [samantamācari].

58641.meaning_1: with all the trimmings; together with all its (necessary or fitting) accessories or constituents; furnished with all accessories
58641.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context, saparivāra means “with all the trimmings”, i.e. giving a gift not alone, but complete with appropriate accessories, furniture, or items that are needed together. The sense broadens from “with an entourage” to “with all fittings; fully equipped (esp. for a gift)”.
58641.sutta_1: bahujanassa sukhāvaho ahosi, ubbegauttāsabhayaṃ apanuditā, dhammikañca rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidhātā, saparivārañca dānaṃ adāsi.
58641.example_1: He conveyed happiness to many people, eliminating threats, terror, and danger, providing just protection and security, and giving gifts with all the trimmings.

52382.meaning_1: danger of death and slaughter; fear of being killed or murdered
52382.meaning_2: horror or fear of death and execution; peril of being subjected to killing
52382.compound_construction: māraṇa ca vadha ca bhaya ca
52382.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context (dn30:1.12.2), the compound refers to the personal realization of the fear or terror experienced in facing fatal violence or mortal peril, including both killing (vadhā) and general danger to life (māraṇa). The context emphasizes a deep awareness of existential threat.
52382.example_1: “Realizing for himself the horrors of death,

51476.meaning_1: danger of death and killing; fear of death or being killed
51476.meaning_2: danger of death or execution; threat of being killed
51476.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
This compound refers to the combined threat of death (maraṇa) or being killed (vadha). In the DN30 context, it means recognizing the risk to one's own life (from any cause or violence), which leads a person to abstain from killing others out of empathy or self-preservation.
51476.example_1:
māraṇavadhabhayattano [maraṇavadhabhayattano,
maraṇavadhabhayamattano] viditvā,
paṭivirato paraṃ māraṇāyahosi,
tena sucaritena saggamagamā [tena so sucaritena saggamagamāsi],
sukataphalavipākamanubhosi.

52379.meaning_2: killing; the act of killing; taking life
52379.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the contextual sentence, māraṇa refers to refraining from the act of killing living beings, i.e. abstaining from taking life.
52379.example_1: he refrained from killing other creatures.

23296.meaning_1: solid food; eatable; chewable and edible
23296.meaning_lit: that which is to be eaten and chewed
23296.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context, “khajjabhojjamatha leyya sāyiyaṃ,” refers specifically to the best of flavors, highlighting “khajjabhojja” as solid eatable foods (chewables and eatables) distinguished from drinkables and lickables, thus in a compound sense: “things to be eaten and chewed.”
23296.example_1: “He used to give the very best of flavors—

70853.meaning_2: tenderness of hands and feet; delicacy of hands and feet
70853.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context (dn30:1.15.7), "hatthapādamudutā" refers to the characteristic of having soft and tender hands and feet, one of the marks of a great person (mahāpurisalakkhaṇa).
70853.example_1: and tender hands and feet are found.

23298.meaning_1: who gets various tasty kinds of food; obtaining every kind of delicious food
23298.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
Used in DN 30 to mean someone who gains the highest variety of delicious foods; denotes the recipient of every kind of eatable (khajja) and consumable (bhojja) with taste (rasa).
23298.example_1: supreme in gaining tasty foods of all sorts,

58810.meaning_1: who has severed all bonds to the household life; who has cut all ties to lay-life
58810.meaning_2: one who cuts through all the bonds of lay/householder existence; one who has broken free from all household constraints
58810.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
Used of someone who has completely relinquished household bonds; contextually describes one who has gone forth, cutting all fetters of householder life (see dn30:1.15.13).
58810.example_1: cutting all bonds of the lay life.’”

2638.meaning_1: beneficial conduct; acting for one's own best interest; action for one's own good
2638.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context (dn30:1.18.2), 'atthacariyatā' refers to conduct (cariya) which benefits oneself (attha), i.e., living for one's own good or acting for one's self-interest (in a positive moral sense).

46223.meaning_1: kind words; endearing speech; speaking kindly
46223.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context from DN 30, piyavāditaṃ refers to speaking kindly or using affectionate words as a means of showing equal and friendly treatment toward others.

59693.meaning_1: fact of having similar interests; (contextually) state of sharing the same desire
59693.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context of DN30, samānachandatā refers to the virtue of having harmonious intentions or interests with others (such as in community living or cooperation). Used with piyavāditā and samānattatā, it highlights shared goodwill and collaborative spirit.
59693.example_1:
dānampi catthacariyatañca [dānampi ca atthacariyatampi ca],
piyavāditañca samānattatañca [piyavadatañca samānachandatañca],
kariyacariyasusaṅgahaṃ bahūnaṃ,
anavamatena guṇena yāti saggaṃ.

20442.meaning_2: tenderness of hands and feet; delicacy of hands and feet
20442.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the contextual sentence (dn30:1.18.7), 'karacaraṇamudutā' refers to the special physical characteristic of the baby prince, indicating that his hands and feet possessed extraordinary softness or tenderness—a mark of a great being according to ancient texts.

65588.meaning_1: acting according to what one says; complying with instruction; responsive to commands
65588.meaning_2: obedient; following what is told; responding to words or speech
65588.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context of dn30:1.18.16, vacanapaṭikara refers to those who listen carefully and act in accordance with the leader's (or teacher's) words and instructions—demonstrating responsiveness or obedience.
65588.example_1: Devoted, they respond to his words;
